712773f-a.text:
42nd Street, east from; Second Avenue. At the left is the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled Children, and at the right the Presbyterian Church of he Covenant, which will be demolished when
Tudor City is built in 1928.
April, 1925.
Brown Brothers.

712786f-a.text:
American Express Company, garage and offices, 219-227 East 42nd Street, north side, between Third and Second Avenues, seen from the clearing on the south side where the Daily News Building is
about to be erected.
March 17, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

712799f-a.text:
216-226 East 42nd Street, south side, between Second and Third Aves. The Daily News Building, East 42nd (left) and 41st (right) Streets, between Third (foreground) and Second Aves., as seen eastward from the Chanin Building. Also shown is a portion of Tudor City silhouetted against the East River and Long Island City. On the extreme left is the Bartholomew Building.
About 1931.
Ewing Galloway.

712800f-a.text:
Daily News Building
East 42nd Street, betw. Second and Third Avenues, Manhattan
Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer
Neg. No. 45
[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code I A-3
Nov. 21, 1935
e. 1N29MUSSUEESbMEENEE 6 ~6S2

712798f.text:
E.42nd St. West from but not including 2nd Ave, prominently shown in the foreground, and on the south side of the street, is the News Bldg. Slightly further westward is the Chanin Bldg (SW corner of Lexington Ave, with the Chrysler Bldg on the opposing (NE)corner of the aforementioned avenue. The dark appearing bldg in the foreground (adjoining the NE corner of 3rd Ave.), upon which is cast the shadow of the News Bldg, is the Bartholomew Bldg, which was the former site of St. Bartholomew's Chapel and Parish House. Adjoining same on the east is the American Express Building.
1936
